questiontext.text:
PART A: Population Mean Sample Size

A researcher wants to estimate the population mean for a environmental monitoring study.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 90%

• Desired margin of error: 1.43 degrees C

• Population standard deviation: 7.97 degrees C (known from previous studies)

What is the minimum sample size of samples required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

PART B: Population Proportion Sample Size

A researcher wants to estimate the population proportion for a quality control study.

Study objective: Determine what proportion of the population will are defective.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 95%

• Desired margin of error: 0.013

• No prior information is available about the population proportion.

What is the minimum sample size required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

Calculate both required sample sizes and explain which study would require more participants.

A researcher wants to estimate the population proportion for a medical research study.

Study objective: Determine what proportion of the population will meet criteria.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 99%

• Desired margin of error: 0.064

• No prior information is available about the population proportion.

What is the minimum sample size required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Proportion

Formula: n = (z² × p × (1-p)) / E²

Where:

• z = critical value for 99% confidence = 2.576

• p = estimated population proportion = 0.5

• E = desired margin of error = 0.064

Using worst-case scenario: p = 0.5, (1-p) = 0.5 (maximum sample size)

Calculation:

n = (2.576² × 0.5 × 0.5) / 0.064²

n = (6.636 × 0.5 × 0.5) / 0.004096

n = 1.6589 / 0.004096

n = 405.02

Since we need a whole number of people, we round UP to: 406 participants

Interpretation: A sample of at least 406 participants is needed to estimate the population proportion within ±0.064 with 99% confidence.

questiontext.text:
A researcher wants to estimate the population mean for a market research survey study.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 95%

• Desired margin of error: 0.35 minutes

• Population standard deviation: 6.11 minutes (known from previous studies)

What is the minimum sample size of customers required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Mean

Formula: n = (z × σ / E)²

Where:

• z = critical value for 95% confidence = 1.96

• σ = population standard deviation = 6.11 minutes

• E = desired margin of error = 0.35 minutes

Calculation:

n = (1.96 × 6.11 / 0.35)²

n = (11.976 / 0.35)²

n = 34.216²

n = 1170.73

Since we need a whole number of customers, we round UP to: 1171 customers

Interpretation: A sample of at least 1171 customers is needed to estimate the population mean within ±0.35 minutes with 95% confidence.

questiontext.text:
A researcher wants to estimate the population proportion for a political polling study.

Study objective: Determine what proportion of the population will support candidate A.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 99%

• Desired margin of error: 0.023

• No prior information is available about the population proportion.

What is the minimum sample size required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Proportion

Formula: n = (z² × p × (1-p)) / E²

Where:

• z = critical value for 99% confidence = 2.576

• p = estimated population proportion = 0.5

• E = desired margin of error = 0.023

Using worst-case scenario: p = 0.5, (1-p) = 0.5 (maximum sample size)

Calculation:

n = (2.576² × 0.5 × 0.5) / 0.023²

n = (6.636 × 0.5 × 0.5) / 0.000529

n = 1.6589 / 0.000529

n = 3136

Since we need a whole number of people, we round UP to: 3137 participants

Interpretation: A sample of at least 3137 participants is needed to estimate the population proportion within ±0.023 with 99% confidence.

questiontext.text:
A researcher wants to estimate the population mean for a medical research study study.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 95%

• Desired margin of error: 4.33 hours

• Population standard deviation: 15.34 hours (known from previous studies)

What is the minimum sample size of subjects required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Mean

Formula: n = (z × σ / E)²

Where:

• z = critical value for 95% confidence = 1.96

• σ = population standard deviation = 15.34 hours

• E = desired margin of error = 4.33 hours

Calculation:

n = (1.96 × 15.34 / 4.33)²

n = (30.066 / 4.33)²

n = 6.944²

n = 48.22

Since we need a whole number of subjects, we round UP to: 49 subjects

Interpretation: A sample of at least 49 subjects is needed to estimate the population mean within ±4.33 hours with 95% confidence.

questiontext.text:
PART A: Population Mean Sample Size

A researcher wants to estimate the population mean for a market research survey study.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 99%

• Desired margin of error: 0.89 hours

• Population standard deviation: 11.97 hours (known from previous studies)

What is the minimum sample size of individuals required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

PART B: Population Proportion Sample Size

A researcher wants to estimate the population proportion for a political polling study.

Study objective: Determine what proportion of the population will favor proposal.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 95%

• Desired margin of error: 0.022

• No prior information is available about the population proportion.

What is the minimum sample size required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

Calculate both required sample sizes and explain which study would require more participants.

A researcher wants to estimate the population mean for a market research survey study.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 99%

• Desired margin of error: 0.9 points

• Population standard deviation: 6.33 points (known from previous studies)

What is the minimum sample size of participants required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Mean

Formula: n = (z × σ / E)²

Where:

• z = critical value for 99% confidence = 2.576

• σ = population standard deviation = 6.33 points

• E = desired margin of error = 0.9 points

Calculation:

n = (2.576 × 6.33 / 0.9)²

n = (16.306 / 0.9)²

n = 18.118²

n = 328.26

Since we need a whole number of participants, we round UP to: 329 participants

Interpretation: A sample of at least 329 participants is needed to estimate the population mean within ±0.9 points with 99% confidence.

questiontext.text:
A researcher wants to estimate the population proportion for a quality control study.

Study objective: Determine what proportion of the population will pass inspection.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 90%

• Desired margin of error: 0.018

• Previous studies suggest that approximately 0.25 of the population will pass inspection.

What is the minimum sample size required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Proportion

Formula: n = (z² × p × (1-p)) / E²

Where:

• z = critical value for 90% confidence = 1.645

• p = estimated population proportion = 0.25

• E = desired margin of error = 0.018

Using prior estimate: p = 0.25, (1-p) = 0.75

Calculation:

n = (1.645² × 0.25 × 0.75) / 0.018²

n = (2.706 × 0.25 × 0.75) / 0.000324

n = 0.5074 / 0.000324

n = 1565.99

Since we need a whole number of people, we round UP to: 1566 participants

Interpretation: A sample of at least 1566 participants is needed to estimate the population proportion within ±0.018 with 90% confidence.

questiontext.text:
A researcher wants to estimate the population mean for a manufacturing quality control study.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 99%

• Desired margin of error: 2.07 seconds

• Population standard deviation: 3.54 seconds (known from previous studies)

What is the minimum sample size of parts required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Mean

Formula: n = (z × σ / E)²

Where:

• z = critical value for 99% confidence = 2.576

• σ = population standard deviation = 3.54 seconds

• E = desired margin of error = 2.07 seconds

Calculation:

n = (2.576 × 3.54 / 2.07)²

n = (9.119 / 2.07)²

n = 4.405²

n = 19.41

Since we need a whole number of parts, we round UP to: 20 parts

Interpretation: A sample of at least 20 parts is needed to estimate the population mean within ±2.07 seconds with 99% confidence.

questiontext.text:
A researcher wants to estimate the population proportion for a political polling study.

Study objective: Determine what proportion of the population will support candidate A.

Given information:

• Desired confidence level: 90%

• Desired margin of error: 0.037

• No prior information is available about the population proportion.

What is the minimum sample size required to achieve this precision?

(Round up to the nearest whole number)

generalfeedback.text:
Solution: Sample Size for Population Proportion

Formula: n = (z² × p × (1-p)) / E²

Where:

• z = critical value for 90% confidence = 1.645

• p = estimated population proportion = 0.5

• E = desired margin of error = 0.037

Using worst-case scenario: p = 0.5, (1-p) = 0.5 (maximum sample size)

Calculation:

n = (1.645² × 0.5 × 0.5) / 0.037²

n = (2.706 × 0.5 × 0.5) / 0.001369

n = 0.6765 / 0.001369

n = 494.16

Since we need a whole number of people, we round UP to: 495 participants

Interpretation: A sample of at least 495 participants is needed to estimate the population proportion within ±0.037 with 90% confidence.
